A new colony is a social experiment writ large. How do we sort ourselves out? How do we organise, govern, trade? Who sets up the infrastructure, and how can they improve on Earth's sometimes poor examples?

Why don't we go to the Moon first? It's easier to access, and could prepare ourselves for how we might deal with Mars. We could set up a lunar base within less than 10 years, but with current technology, it's not very feasible on Mars, at least with NASA's current budget. A trip back to the Moon would be far less costly, far more effective in studying the effects of low-gravity, testing out how bases on other planets and moons would work out, and eventually lunar tourism (whereas mars tourism is much more difficult). It takes only 3 days to get to the Moon, while it takes ≈7 months to get to Mars. From this perspective, supplies and people can more easily travel to the Moon and back if necessary. This means that a moon colony will develop much more quickly than a mars colony would, and citizens can evacuate to the Earth in an emergency. Not to mention its easier to land and take off from the lunar surface. Sure, Mars may have somewhat superior resources, heavier gravity, and there's that possibility of life, but in order to have humans succeed in the future in the solar system, we need to learn how to take care of our own earth life and spread it to other planets and moons. We basically need to practice on the Moon for a much more difficult Mars mission farther in the future. The rest of the globe agrees that we should go back to the Moon. Right now, the European Space Agency is planning it, China has probes on the planet, and the Google X Prize competition is encouraging companies to put rovers on the Moon! In my eyes, it would be alarming if NASA, which currently holds 60% of all space agency funding in the world, did not listen to everyone's pleas. We can do it, and we should.
